title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to change procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code changes procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations, including the jurisdiction and procedures for issuing warrants by a court of competent jurisdiction. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code expands the definition of courts with jurisdiction to issue warrants in investigations. This includes district courts and courts of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated and located in the district of the service provider. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code broadens the definition of courts authorized to issue search warrants in investigations. This includes district courts, courts of appeals, and state courts with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated. The amendment expands the courts authorized to issue search warrants to include those with jurisdiction over the offense, where the provider of communication service is located, where a person subject to certain sections is located, or acting on a foreign assistance request. The amendment allows Federal judges to issue orders to assist foreign authorities in criminal investigations and prosecutions upon application by the Department of Justice. Federal judges can issue orders in criminal proceedings related to offenses, including forfeiture, sentencing, and restitution. These orders may include search warrants and warrants for electronic communications. In criminal proceedings, federal judges can issue orders for search warrants, electronic communication warrants, pen registers, trap and trace devices, and orders for testimony or document production. In criminal proceedings, federal judges can issue orders for search warrants, electronic communication warrants, pen registers, trap and trace devices, and orders for testimony or document production. Additionally, a Federal judge may appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents as requested by a foreign authority. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders for appearance, production of documents, administer oaths, and take testimony or statements. The Federal judge can appoint a person to take testimony, statements, or documents as requested by a foreign authority. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders for appearance, document production, administer oaths, and receive documents or other things. An application for execution of a request from a foreign authority can be filed in the district where the person resides, where the documents are located, or in any district if multiple locations are involved. The search warrant limitation under this section requires an application to be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. A Federal judge may issue a search warrant based on this standard. A Federal judge may issue a search warrant under this section if the foreign offense involves conduct punishable by imprisonment for more than one year in the US. The warrant can be served anywhere in the US, and nothing in this section prevents foreign authorities or interested parties from seeking assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions. The section defines key terms for obtaining assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions, including the meanings of "Federal judge" and "foreign authority." The curr_chunk adds definitions for key terms related to obtaining assistance in criminal investigations or prosecutions, including "Federal judge" and "foreign authority." The curr_chunk introduces definitions for terms related to foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions.
